title: Game Theory – Dominant Strategy
description: Identify dominant strategies and understand when they exist.

questions.question: A dominant strategy for a player is one that:
options: Yields the highest payoff regardless of the opponent’s move
questions.explanation: Dominance is payoff-maximization independent of opponents.

questions.question: If A’s payoffs by rows against any column are (5 vs 3), A’s dominant choice is:
questions.explanation: 5 > 3 for every column → that row dominates.

questions.question: Dominant strategies:
questions.explanation: Many games don’t have dominant strategies.

questions.question: The Prisoner’s Dilemma features:
options: A dominant strategy for only one player

questions.question: If only Player A has a dominant strategy, equilibrium will be:
options: Likely formed by A’s dominant action and B’s best response
questions.explanation: B best-responds to A’s dominant choice → a Nash equilibrium.

questions.question: To detect dominance in a payoff matrix, compare A’s:
questions.explanation: Check each column, pick row with higher A payoff.

questions.question: Which statement is FALSE?
options: Dominant strategy may be inefficient collectively
Dominant strategy is independent of the opponent’s move
questions.explanation: Dominant strategies often do not exist.

questions.question: If two strategies give identical payoffs in every column, then:
options: They are equivalent for the player
questions.explanation: They are payoff-equivalent; either can be chosen.

questions.question: Weak dominance means:
options: A strategy is better in all cases
A strategy is at least as good in all cases and strictly better in some
questions.explanation: Weakly dominant ≥ in all states, > in some.

questions.question: Strict dominance implies that the dominated strategy is:
questions.explanation: Strictly dominated strategies cannot be best responses.
